title-group.article-title: Primary Repair of Internal Carotid Artery Aneurysm Secondary to Kinking and Cystic Medial Degeneration

article-meta.aff: 2Faculty of Medicine, University of Belgrade, Serbia

author-notes.corresp: Slobodan Tanaskovic, Vascular surgery Clinic, “Dedinje” Cardiovascular Institute, Heroja Milana Tepica 1 Street, 11000 Belgrade, Serbia. Email: drslobex@yahoo.com

sec.title: Introduction:
sec.p: In this report, we aim to present a very rare case of internal carotid artery (ICA) aneurysm secondary to kinking and cystic medial degeneration.

sec.title: Case report:
sec.p: A 66-year-old female patient was admitted to our institution for multidetector computed tomography (MDCT) angiography of supra-aortic trunks. On admission, she complained of occasional dizziness; 2 months earlier ascending aorta reconstruction was done for aneurysmal disease. Color Doppler ultrasonography and MDCT arteriography revealed significant right ICA kinking associated with large aneurysm, 24.6 × 24.5 mm2 in diameter. Aneurysm resection was done followed by ICA reconstruction by end-to-end anastomosis. Pathohistological findings of aneurysmal sac revealed cystical medial degeneration with inflammatory infiltrate mostly consisting of lymphocytes and fibrovascular proliferation.

sec.title: Conclusion:
sec.p: This is the first case that describes mutual contribution of cystic medial degeneration and ICA kinking in carotid aneurysm disease etiology successfully treated by aneurysm resection.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Extracranial internal carotid artery (EICA) aneurysms are uncommon entities, estimated at 0.1% to 2% of total carotid surgery procedures performed at major referral centers. 1 The exact incidence is not entirely known, but it is expected to be about 0.8% to 1% of all arterial aneurysms and about 4% of all peripheral arterial aneurysms in reported studies. 2 They could be determined by atherosclerosis, dysplasia, infection, trauma, or iatrogenic cause. 3

Cystic media necrosis (CMN) is a pathological phenomenon that is characterized by media degenerative disruptions of collagen, elastin, and smooth muscles resulting in arterial wall failing. 4 –6 It can be seen in the aortic tissues of patients with various abnormalities such as Marfan syndrome, aortic dissection, aortic aneurysm, atherosclerosis, congenital heart disease, or even healthy individuals. Carotid localization of CMN has been mentioned as well. 7

On the other hand, only a few case reports have been published so far describing relationship between internal carotid artery (ICA) kinking and aneurysmal growth. 8,9 In this report, we aim to present a very rare case of large ICA aneurysm secondary to kinking and cystic medial degeneration.

sec.title: Case Report
sec.p: A 66-year-old female patient was admitted to our institution for multidetector computed tomography (MDCT) angiography of supra-aortic branches. On admission, she complained of occasional dizziness; color Doppler ultrasonography described right ICA kinking with saccular aneurysm approximately 20 mm in diameter.

Two months ago, resection of ascending aorta aneurysm was done followed by tubular graft interposition and aortic valve suspension. Her medical history included hypertension and hyperlipidemia. She denied any previous trauma.

The next day we did MDCT arteriography on “General Electrics” 64-slice device (GE Light speed VCT64, GE Healthcare, Milwaukee, WI, USA.). During the procedure, 100 mL of “Ultravist” contrast media was administrated, intersections were made at 0.625 mm, 3-dimensional volume was rendered, and maximum/minimum intensity projection modalities were used for the final imaging. The MDCT arteriography revealed right ICA kinking with large aneurysm 24.6 × 24.5 mm2 in diameter (Figures 1A and B and 2A and B). Left ICA was also kinked and positioned subcranially.

caption.p: A (on the left) and B (on the right), Multidetector computed tomography angiography showing right internal carotid artery aneurysm and relationship to surrounding structures.
A (on the left) and B (on the right), Multidetector computed tomography arteriography of right internal carotid artery aneurysm—24.6 × 24.5 mm2 in diameter.

sec.p: Surgical treatment was indicated which consisted of aneurysmal resection and ICA reconstruction by end-to-end anastomosis. After platysma dissection, we exposed carotid bifurcation. Large saccular aneurysm was identified on the basis of kinked ICA localized approximately 2 cm from its origin (Figures 3 and 4).

caption.p: Intraoperative findings of kinked right internal carotid artery with aneurysmal formation.
Right internal carotid artery aneurysm—intraoperative findings.

sec.p: After heparin administration and carotid arteries, clamping aneurysmal sac was completely resected (Figure 5) followed by end-to-end ICA reconstruction with a 6/0 polypropylene suture along with the shortening of the artery (Figure 6A and B). Clamping time was 8 minutes.

caption.p: A (on the left) and B (on the right), Internal carotid artery reconstruction by end-to-end anastomosis.

sec.p: Aneurysmal sac was sent for pathohistological analysis (Figure 7), which revealed cystic medial degeneration with inflammatory infiltrate mostly consisting of lymphocytes and fibrovascular proliferation (Figure 8A and B). Atherosclerotic alterations in the arterial wall with dystrophic calcification were described as well.

caption.p: Internal carotid artery aneurysm specimen sent for pathohistological analysis.

A and B, Pathohistological findings. Hematoxylin and eosin staining; magnification ×100 (on the left) and ×200 (on the right) showing characteristic pathognomonic findings for cystic medial degeneration.

sec.p: In the postoperative course, transient recurrent laryngeal nerve paresis was noted, which was successfully treated by corticosteroids. The patient was discharged from our institution on the 7th postoperative day. After 6-month follow-up, the patient was doing well, and Doppler ultrasonography showed regular ICA flow.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Since in our case 3 rare entities were present at the same time, we made a brief review of the CMN, extracranial ICA aneurysm, and carotid pathological elongations and its mutual contribution to pathology described in our case.

Cystic media necrosis is a large arteries disorder, characterized by basophilic ground substance accumulation in the media with cyst-like lesions. 4 –6 The term cystic medial necrosis is sometimes replaced by cystic medial degeneration, as necrosis is not always present in the pathological progress. 4 The prevalence of CMN is estimated to be around 6% in patients with thoracic aortic aneurysm, 10 but it was present in 42.9% of the patients with Turner syndrome as well. 11 Although its main localization is in the aorta, CMN has been described as carotid aneurysm cause as well. 7 The CMN can be seen in patients with or without Marfan syndrome and is usually present in young patients. Treatment of aortic pathology related to CMN consists of antihypertensive and surgical therapy. Bentall operation performed for ascending aorta aneurysm in patients with CMN but without Marfan syndrome had better long-term cardiovascular event-free rate (68%) than in patients with Marfan syndrome and CMN (28%). 12,13

As mentioned earlier, EICA aneurysms are extremely rare with reported incidence of 0.8% to 1% of all arterial aneurysms and about 4% of all peripheral arterial aneurysms. 1,2 In many cases they occur spontaneously, on the basis of atherosclerosis, but could also be triggered by blunt trauma of the injured vessels, thus presenting as pseudoaneurysm. 14,15

Carotid aneurysm could also occur after dissection, about 30% of all carotid dissections are associated with aneurysmal growth. 16 Symptoms of EICA aneurysms could be various, small aneurysms are usually asymptomatic, only recognized as a pulsatile mass of the neck, while larger aneurysm could cause pain, swelling, or difficulty in neck movement. The EICA aneurysm complications could be rupture, complete thrombosis followed by cerebral ischemic events or distal cerebral embolization in case of parietal thrombosis. Therefore, if left untreated, mortality and morbidity rate of these patients is very high. Preferred surgical treatment is aneurysm resection followed by ICA reconstruction with reported mortality rate of less than 2%. 1

Endovascular procedures with stent or stent graft implantation have been described in EICA aneurysm treatment as well with satisfactory outcome. 17
–21 Nevertheless, there is a high risk of distal embolization while its use is contraindicated if infection is present.

As for pathological elongations, ICA morphological abnormalities in the form of kinking and coiling are described to be associated with increased risk of the thromboembolic events due to endothelial lesions induced by local flow modifications at the site of arterial twisting followed by cerebral ischemic symptoms. 22 –24 In kinking formation, usually ICA is affected and assumed to have an “S” shape. Kinks are found to be 4 times more common in women than in men. 25 The true incidence is unknown due to the absence of symptoms, but when ischemia symptoms are present they manifest as transient ischemic attack, stroke, amaurosis fugax, and so on. Most of these symptoms occur due to turbulent flow through kinked ICA, leading to intimal ulcerations and embolization.

In our case report, ICA aneurysm occurred due to endothelial lesion induced by flow modifications on the basis of severe ICA kinking and cystic medial degeneration presence. Since 2 months prior to admission, our patient had ascending aorta resection done for aneurysmal disease; we believe that CMN was probably present in the thoracic aorta as well, considering that this is the typical CMN location, but the specimen was not sent for pathohistological analysis at the time. A few case reports described the relationship between ICA kinking and aneurysmal growth, 8
,9 but mutual contribution of CMN and ICA kinking in carotid aneurysm disease etiology has not been described yet.

Surgical treatment of extracranial ICA aneurysms represents one of the most challenging and demanding fields in vascular surgery. 1,2,14,26 Good surgical technique is required with clear and precise preoperative tactic. Appropriate proximal and distal exposure of carotid arteries is required for better visibility and safer reconstruction.

In the case presented, ICA aneurysm associated with kinking contributed to specific surgical approach. Based on our experience in extracranial carotid aneurysms surgical treatment, 26 we believed that complete aneurysm exclusion followed by primary end-to-end anastomosis would be the most suitable solution. Intraoperatively, good quality of ICA wall was verified below and beyond the aneurysm, so end-to-end anastomosis was an elegant and feasible treatment option. Except for transient hypertension, otherwise postoperative course was uneventful. Careful preoperative planning, appropriate exposure, short clamping time, and prompt reconstruction contributed to good final outcome in the case presented.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In the case presented, surgical treatment of this rare case of ICA aneurysm secondary to kinking and cystic medial degeneration showed satisfactory results.
